speaker: Facebook posts
vclaim: According to Attorney General William Bar on Twitter, "Iran has given United States dollars to taxpayers" even Iran can buy uranium from Russia.
date: stated on October 13, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, Bar didn't tweet that the United States gave Iran tax dollars so that Iran could buy uranium from Russia.
text: U.S. Attorney William Bar did not tweet about Iran using US tax dollars to purchase uranium from Russia. He's not using a personal account, for one reason. If you look at the Twitter account that he claims to be, you will notice one gift: there is a third litre in his first name. A footage of tweeting was exchanged on Facebook, making it look like a bar that wrote: "See if you can follow this. The President of the United States gave IRAN United States dollars to taxpayers until Iran could buy U.S. uranium from Russia that just got 20% of our uranium to FREE. So Iran used the U.S. to buy uranium to destroy the U.S. and everything the U.S. government made possible. The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) On January 12, 2021, he wrote in an Instagram article saying that Joe Biden remained silent about the violence in Black Lives-Mite protests. By Tom Kircher: January 16, 2021, the tweet was published by a sarcastic account using the wrong handle to spell out the name of Bar, "@AGWilliam Barr." The sarcastic tweet mixes two floors. We have already verified the allegations surrounding the 2015 agreement with Iran called for by President Barack Obama. This package launched the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan, releasing frozen Iranian assets and lifting economic sanctions, including Iran and the United States, as well as China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom and the European Union. In contrast, Iran opened its doors to international inspections and dismantled key parts of its nuclear programme. In 2018, President Donald Trump withdrew from the deal. This is the money that the United States made from Iran (it was not tax dollars). The reference to Russia stems from the sale of a uranium company in the United States to a Russian company that is often misunderstood. The two events are by no means linked. We're assessing this ex-tweet receptor on fire!
